Expectation1: Stay updated on changes in laws and legal precedents.
Situation1: In the middle of jury instructions, your clerk hands you an alert that the Supreme Court has just issued a ruling that directly overturns the key precedent your current instructions are based on. You must stop immediately.
Expectation2: Follow the instructions and guidelines provided by the volunteer coordinator
Situation2: New safety steps were highlighted during the last briefing and everyone was asked to apply them consistently.
Story: As I stood at the bench, reading jury instructions aloud, my clerk slipped me a note. The Supreme Court had just overturned the precedent I was relying on. My mind raced—every word I said next could be wrong, misleading, even unjust. I was expected, as a judge, to stay current, to pivot instantly when the law changed. But I was also a volunteer at the community center, where just yesterday, the coordinator emphasized the importance of following new safety protocols without deviation. I’d promised to model consistency and reliability for the team. Now, in court, I was being asked to do the opposite: to halt, to change course midstream, to abandon the script for the sake of justice. My heart pounded as I weighed the expectations—steadfastness and adaptability, clarity and uncertainty—each role demanding something different, each voice in my head growing louder as I stood, silent, in front of the waiting jury.
